p: Platelet cell membranes, and atherosclerotic plaques, have both CB 1 and CB 2. [ 4] Low-dose oral THC inhibits atherosclerosis progression via pleiotropic immunomodulatory effects in apolipoprotein-E knockout models, [ 9] as well as inhibiting lymphoid proliferation and macrophage chemotaxis, in a dose-dependent manner. [ 4, 9] This effect can also be inhibited by a CB 2 antagonist. [ 4] A similar function was observed for CB 2 in vascular smooth muscle cells in coronary arteries. Depending on receptor activation, the ECS can promote destruction of plaques; a potential druggable target.
